newsitem.title: POLAND: LOT sets up domestic flights subsidary.
newsitem.headline: LOT sets up domestic flights subsidary.

text.p: Poland's state-owned national carrier PLL LOT SA has set up a fully-owned subsidary Eurolot to operate its current domestic and regional flights and launch new flights, LOT's president said on Tuesday.

Jan Litwinski told a news conference the new firm, due to start operations in April, was set in line with LOT's strategy of focusing on its profitable international flights and transfering other non-core operations to subsidiaries.

"In LOT's strategy there is no room for expanding in domestic and regional flights so this moment seems suitable to set up such a firm...the idea was also to lower LOT's deficit (on domestic operations)," he said.

Litwinski said a specialised domestic and regional carrier would be better positioned to develop new connections and win LOT expected the domestic flights would bring it a nine-million-zloty loss in 1996.
Mariusz Tazbir, a member of Eurolot's management, also present, suggested the firm was likely to stay in the red next year and did not say when it could start bringing profits.

The new firm was expected to have 356,000 passengers on domestic flights in the 1997 summer season, and 480,000 passengers on both domestic and short-distance international flights to smaller centres.
LOT carried 203,000 passengers on domestic flights in the summer season this year.
Litwinski did not rule out a sale of a part of Eurolot, but did not give any details.
"There is an interest in the project...and we are open for proposals, but first we want to start operating," he said.
Eurolot would operate renting LOT's aircraft, but Litwinski said the company planned to buy new 19 or 30-seat planes.
"We are negotiating with four aircraft suppliers," he said.
